data.body:
Hi,

I'm working on a game for Android with MonoGame, and I'm using the same method to handle multiple screen resolutions that most people use after google searching for it (this one: http://infinitespace-studios.co.uk/2012/07/19/handling-multiple-screen-resolutions-in-monogame-for-android-part-1/ ). I use this method (with tiny changes) on a game I've already released, and it works perfectly, but when I try to use the same code as in that other game to scale the screen in this game, it only works SOME of the time. Anyone else had this problem or has heard of it and know of a solution?Let me know what more I need to post if this doesn't tell you what you need to know about the issue.

data.title: Windows 8: touch point gets "stuck" after using XAML/SIP on touch screen device
data.body:
I've found what appears to be a bug in the public release of MonoGame3 running in Windows 8 on a touch screen device (Surface RT). Attached is a simple example project that can be used to reproduce the problem.

Description of problem:
After displaying a simple piece of XAML which includes a text field, setting focus to the text field so that the SIP appears, and then scrolling the XAML content, a touch point is added to the array returned by each call to TouchPanel.GetState() that remains even after contact is released from the screen and cannot be removed.

Attachment:
http://www.adamdawes.com/private/MonoGameStuckTouchpoint.zip

Example project:
The project is a simple empty MonoGame Windows Store project, inside which a couple of XAML controls have been added to the GamePage. These include a textbox and a button, and are initially collapsed so that they cannot be seen.

In the game's Update function, the code checks to see whether a single touch point with a state of "Pressed" has been encountered. If so, it makes the XAML controls visible and sets the focus to the textbox. This causes the SIP to appear on a touch device. Due to the way Windows handles scrolling, the OK button is hidden behind the SIP.

If the user swipes the main area of the page (above the SIP) upwards to reveal the OK button, a touch point ends up "stuck" in MonoGame and is returned from every call to TouchPanel.GetState(), even though the user has released contact with the screen.

To reproduce:
- Run the attached project on a touch screen device with no hardware keyboard (e.g., Surface)
- Note that the project continually displays the number of items returned from TouchPanel.GetState into the debug window (initially always zero).
- Tap the screen. The XAML controls appear, as does the SIP. Because the textbox has focus, it scrolls upwards so that it is displayed immediately above the SIP.
- The debug output still shows zeros at this point.
- Swipe the "non-SIP" part of the screen upwards to reveal the OK button, and release contact with the screen. The debug output now continually shows "1" instead of "0". An unexpected touch point is constantly present within the Touch Panel and cannot be removed.

I've experienced this a couple of times but only yesterday tracked down what was triggering it. This is causing me some real problems in my games as when I ask the user to enter their name for the high-score table, should they happen to scroll the XAML controls then the game locks up due to this unexpected touch point and has to be closed. A workaround and/or fix would be very much appreciated.

data.title: Android: SoundEffect and Songs not loading
data.body:
I am using a simple:  Content.Load<SoundEffect>("pathToSoundFile") and I just don't see how this could ever work.

The content loading code in MonoGame eventually hits ReadAsset<T> which hands off to the SoundEffectReader which creates a SoundEffect using this constructor:

SoundEffect(string name, byte[] data)

The SoundEffect creates a Sound (android specific type)  using this constructor:

Sound(byte[] audiodata, float volume, bool looping)

which is basically not implemented.  It just sets the _soundId to 0 which is the same as being disposed.  It never gets set anywhere else except for the alternate constructor:

Sound(string filename, float volume, bool looping)

Tracing back, this will only get hit if ContentManager decides to use ReadRawAsset<T> instead of ReadAsset<T>.

ReadRawAsset<T> will only get hit if the inital ReadAsset<T> path encounters an exception.  It does seem odd to me that the only way to correctly load a sound effect file is to first hit an exception one way, then load it another way.

But I'm not even hitting an exception so the sound effect is basically "dead".  I see commented out code for "throw new NotImplementedException();" in the Sound constructor so perhaps it used to...

What is the correct way to load Sound content on Android?

data.title: Add ColorWriteEnable To MGFX
SpriteFont implementation does not handle left-side overhang of the first character in a line
data.body:
When the first character in a line of text overhangs to the left, XNA's SpriteFont implementation offsets the text to the right so that the string as a whole does not overflow its measured rectangle. MonoGame currently doesn't do this, so fonts with this kind of overhang will exceed their measured bounds (and get cut off if being drawn at the edges of a screen/render target).

I have a preliminary implementation of this here:
https://github.com/kevingadd/MonoGame/commit/40f155c56a414024ad7baf455be73118f346f886

data.title: Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Keyboard not working in Windows Phone 8
data.body:
XNA on WP7 allowed full interaction with a hardware keyboard for the handful of devices that had one. MonoGame running on Windows Phone 8 doesn't appear to offer any keyboard support. Of course there aren't any WP8 devices with hardware keyboards AFAIA, so this isn't particularly urgent just at the moment; I'm testing this by running in the emulator with "keyboard" mode activated by pressing Page Down.

The KeyboardState,IsKeyDown always returns false for all keys, and the GetPressedKeys function always returns an empty array.

It would be good to get this fixed up for a future release.

data.title: Removed minVertexIndex Exception
data.body:
This removes the exception on minVertexIndex in GraphicsDevice.DrawIndexedPrimitives().

minVertexIndex and numVertices are simply hints for software vertex processing.

 http://blogs.msdn.com/b/jsteed/archive/2004/07/16/drawindexedprimitive-demystified.aspx

> The MinIndex and NumVertices values are really just hints 
> to help Direct3D optimize memory access during software 
> vertex processing, and could simply be set to include the 
> entire vertex buffer at the price of performance.

Since DirectX11 and OpenGL do not support such hints these parameters are currently unused in MonoGame.  We leave them only for compatibility with XNA.

data.title: Fix BlendState Exception From SharpDX
data.body:
This fixes the issue addressed in this comment...

 https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1166#issuecomment-13362051

The core issue is that you cannot pass color blend enum values to alpha blend state.  So for example this is technically illegal:

```
var state = new BlendState();
state.AlphaSourceBlend = Blend.SourceColor;
```

MS XNA doesn't care...  it seems to do the translation for the user under the hood to keep DirectX happy.

This isn't a problem on OpenGL either because we do not support separate alpha blending on that platform.

MonoGame under DirectX wasn't doing the translation causing exceptions to be thrown by SharpDX.

I also fixed MGFX processing to do the same correct translation when building the shader render states.

data.title: Fixed MGFX To Not Generate Default SampleState.
data.body:
The MGFX processor was generating a default SampleState when a user did not specify any SampleState parameters in his FX file.

This code change only affects the 2MGFX tool which currently only works on Windows.

data.title: SongReader incorrectly prepends a forward slash in iOS when the ContentManager.RootDirectory is null/empty, causing crash
data.body:
I'm loading a .mp3 into a SongReader.  The problem ultimately is that the following lines of code in the Song constructor cause a crash:

```
    internal Song(string fileName)
    {           
        _name = fileName;
     #if IOS
        _sound = AVAudioPlayer.FromUrl(NSUrl.FromFilename(fileName));
     Crash here---> _sound.NumberOfLoops = 0;
                    ...
```

The reason the crash occurs is because _sound is null.  The reason _sound is null is because fileName was:

```
   (notice the '/' at the beginning of the file name)
   /content/screens/globalcontentscreen/MenuSong.mp3
```

I ran some tests and it seems if the leading slash is present, then AVAudioPlayer.FromUrl returns a null instance.  If the leading slash is not there, then AVAudioPlayer.FromUrl works just fine.

So I researched why the leading slash exists and it's because the caller of the Song constructor (SongReader) is inappropriately putting a leading slash on this line of code:

```
path = input.ContentManager.RootDirectory + separator + path;
```

In my case input.ContentManager.RootDirectory is empty (it's "" ).

I believe the code should be:

```
if(!string.IsNullOrEmpty(input.ContentManager.RootDirectory))
{
     path = input.ContentManager.RootDirectory + separator + path;
}
```
